a.g: Has there [not] come upon man a period of time when he was not a thing [even] mentioned?
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 9a
Indeed, know that arrogance [kibr] is among the destroyers, and no one among creation is free from some measure of it. Its removal is an individual obligation [fard 'ayn], and it is not removed by mere wishing, but rather by treatment and the application of remedies that suppress it. In its treatment are two stations: the first is the eradication of its root from its origin and the uprooting of its tree from its planting in the heart [qalb]. The first station is in eradicating its root, and its treatment is both intellectual ['ilmi] and practical ['amali], and healing is not complete except by their combination. As for the intellectual: it is that he knows himself and knows his Lord, the Most High, and that suffices him in removing arrogance [kibr]. For whenever he knows himself with true knowledge [ma'rifa], he knows that he is more abased than every abased one and lesser than every small thing, and that nothing befits him except humility [tawadu'], abasement [dhilla], and lowliness. And when he knows his Lord, he knows that grandeur ['azama] and majesty [kibriya'] are only befitting for Allah. As for knowing himself, that is also lengthy, but we mention from it what is beneficial in arousing humility [tawadu'] and abasement [dhilla]. It suffices him to know the meaning of a single verse in the Book of Allah, for the Qur'an is the knowledge ['ilm] of the first and the last for one whose insight [basira] has been opened. And He, the Most High, has said: "Perished is man [insan]; how ungrateful he is! From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] He created him and proportioned him. Then He made the way easy for him. Then He causes him to die and puts him in a grave. Then when He wills, He will resurrect him." (76:1-3) The verse has pointed to the first creation of man [insan]: he was not a thing mentioned, and he was in the realm of non-existence for ages—indeed, his non-existence had no beginning. And what thing is more vile and lesser than obliteration and non-existence? He was like that in pre-eternity. Then Allah created him from the vilest of things, then from the filthiest of them, for He created him from dust, then from a sperm-drop [nutfa], then from a clinging clot ['alaqa], then from a lump of flesh [mudgha], then He made him bones, then He clothed the bones with flesh. This was the beginning of his existence, when he became a thing mentioned. He did not become a thing mentioned except while being upon the vilest of descriptions and attributes! For he was not created complete at his beginning; rather, He created him as an inanimate, dead thing—he did not hear, nor see, nor feel, nor move, nor speak, nor grasp, nor perceive, nor know. He began with his death before his life, and with his weakness before his strength, and with his ignorance before his knowledge ['ilm], and with his blindness before his sight, and with his deafness before his hearing, and with his muteness before his speech, and with his misguidance before his guidance, and with his poverty before his wealth, and with his incapacity before his power. This is the meaning of His saying: "From what thing did He create him? From a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed?" (76:2) and the meaning of His saying: "Has there [not] come upon man [insan] a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned? Indeed, We created man [insan] from a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed that We may try him..." (76:1-2) Thus He created him first, then bestowed favor upon him, saying: "Then He made the way easy for him." (76:3) This is a reference to what was facilitated for him during the period of his life until death. And similarly He said: "From a sperm-drop [nutfa] mixed that We may try him; so We made him hearing and seeing. Indeed, We guided him to the way, be he grateful or be he ungrateful." (76:2-3) Its meaning is that He gave him life after he was an inanimate, dead thing—dust first and a sperm-drop [nutfa] second. And He gave him hearing after he was deaf, and sight after he was lacking vision, and strength after weakness, and knowledge ['ilm] after ignorance, and created for him limbs with their wonders and signs after their absence, and enriched him after poverty, and satiated him after hunger, and clothed him after nakedness, and guided him after misguidance. So look how He managed him and formed him, and to the way how He made it easy, and to the transgression of man [insan]—how ungrateful he is!—and to the ignorance of man [insan] how He made it manifest? So He said: "Does not man [insan] see that We created him from a sperm-drop [nutfa]? And at once he is a clear adversary. And of His signs is that He created you from dust; then, suddenly you were human beings dispersing [throughout the earth]." (36:77, 30:20) So look at the favor [ni'ma] of Allah upon him, how He transferred him from that abasement [dhilla], insignificance, vileness, and filth to this elevation and honor, so he became existent after non-existence, alive after death, speaking after muteness, seeing after blindness, strong after weakness, knowing after ignorance, guided after misguidance, capable after incapacity, and rich after poverty? He was, in his essence, nothing. And what thing is viler than nothing? And what insignificance is less than pure non-existence? Then he became, by Allah, a thing. He only created him from the abased dust [turab] that is trodden underfoot and the filthy sperm-drop [nutfa] after pure non-existence also to make him know the vileness of his essence, so that he may know himself by it. And He only perfected the favor [ni'ma] upon him so that he may know his Lord by it and know by it His grandeur ['azama] and majesty [jalal], and that majesty [kibriya'] is only befitting for Him, Glorified and Exalted. And for that reason, He bestowed favor upon him, saying: "Have We not made for him two eyes and a tongue and two lips? And have shown him the two ways?" (90:8-10) And He made known his vileness first, saying: "Was he not a sperm-drop [nutfa] from semen emitted? Then he was a clinging clot ['alaqa]..." (75:37-38) Then He mentioned His favor [minna] upon him, saying: "Then He created and proportioned. And made from him the two sexes, male and female." (75:38-39) So that his existence may continue through procreation, just as his existence first occurred through invention. So, one whose beginning is this and whose states are these—from where does he get pride, arrogance [kibr], boasting, and haughtiness, when he is, in truth, the vilest of the vile and the weakest of the weak?
Vol4 book5
Indeed, he who seeks sufficiency [al-kifayah] from other than Him and abandons reliance [al-tawakkul] is the one who denies this verse. For it is a question posed in the manner of an interrogation with the truth [al-haqq], like His saying, exalted is He: "Has there come upon man a period of time when he was not a thing remembered?"
j4 k09
Indeed, look upon the gentleness [lutf] and the generosity [karam], then upon the power [qudrah] and the wisdom [hikmah]—the wonders of the Divine Presence [al-hadrah al-rabbaniyyah] will dazzle you. And the greatest wonder of all is of one who sees beautiful calligraphy or a beautiful design upon a wall, admires it, and then directs all his concern to pondering the designer and the calligrapher—how he designed it and wrote it, and how he mastered it. He continues to hold it in great esteem within himself, saying, "How skillful he is! How perfect his craftsmanship! How excellent his ability!" Then he looks upon these wonders within himself and in others, yet he is heedless of its Maker and its Fashioner. His majesty does not astonish him, nor does His grandeur and His wisdom confound him. This is but a glimpse of the wonders of your own body, which cannot be fully enumerated. It is the closest field for your reflection [fikr] and the clearest witness to the majesty of your Creator. Yet you are heedless of that, preoccupied with your belly and your private parts. You know nothing of yourself except that you hunger so you eat, become satiated so you sleep, feel desire so you copulate, and become angry so you fight. All the beasts share with you in this knowledge. The specific characteristic of the human being, which the beasts are veiled from, is the knowledge [ma'rifah] of God, the Exalted, through contemplation of the dominion [mulk] of the heavens and the earth and the wonders of the horizons and the souls [anfus]. For through this, the servant enters the company of the angels brought near and is resurrected in the company of the prophets and the truthful, brought near to the Presence [hadrah] of the Lord of the worlds. This station is not for the beasts, nor is it for the human who is content with the desires [shahawat] of the beasts in this world [dunya]. For he is worse than the beasts by far, for the beast has no capacity for that, while he—God created for him the capacity, then he left it idle and was ungrateful for God's favor in it. Those are like cattle; rather, they are more astray in path. And when you know the path of reflection [fikr] within yourself, then reflect upon the earth, which is your resting place, then upon its rivers, its mountains, and its mines. Then ascend from it to the dominion [mulk] of the heavens. As for the earth, among His signs is that He created the earth as a carpet and a cradle, and He placed therein broad roads, and He made it subservient that you may travel its tracts, and He made it stable, not moving, and He set therein mountains as pegs for it, preventing it from shaking. Then He expanded its expanses until the children of Adam fell short of reaching all its regions, even if their lifespans were long and their travels many. So the Exalted said: **"And the heaven—We constructed it with strength, and indeed, We are [its] expander. And the earth—We spread it, and excellent are the spreaders."** And He, the Exalted, said: **"It is He who made the earth subservient for you, so walk through its tracts."** And He, the Exalted, said: **"[He] who made for you the earth a carpet."** And He has frequently mentioned this in His Mighty Book.

a.g: Indeed, We created man from a sperm-drop mixture that We may try him; and We made him hearing and seeing.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 9a
Indeed, "From a mingled drop [nutfah amshaj] We test him, and We made him hearing and seeing. Indeed, We have guided him to the path, whether he be grateful [shakiran] or ungrateful [kafuran]." And its meaning is that He gave him life [ahyahu] after he was a lifeless, dead thing, dust [turaban] at first and a drop [nutfah] second, and gave him hearing after he was deaf, and gave him sight after he lacked vision, and gave him strength after weakness, and gave him knowledge [‘allamahu] after ignorance [jahl], and created for him limbs containing wonders and signs after their absence, and enriched him after poverty, and satisfied him after hunger, and clothed him after nakedness, and guided him [hadahu] after misguidance [dalal].
Vol3 book 9a
Indeed, this is the meaning of His saying, "From what thing did We create man? From a mixed drop [nutfah amshaj]." The verse has pointed to the first creation of man: he was not a thing mentioned [shay'an madhkuran], and he was in the realm of non-existence [‘adam] for ages—indeed, his non-existence had no beginning. And what thing is more base and lesser than obliteration and non-existence? He was like this in eternity. Then Allah created him from the vilest of things, then from the filthiest of them, for He created him from dust [turab], then from a drop [nutfah], then from a clinging clot [‘alaqah], then from a chewed lump [mudghah], then He made him bones [‘azman], then He clothed the bones with flesh [lahman]. This was the beginning of his existence, when he became a thing mentioned [shay'an madhkuran]. He did not become a thing mentioned except while in the most base of states and descriptions! For he was not created complete at his beginning; rather, He created him as a lifeless, dead mineral [jumadan mayyitan]—he did not hear, nor see, nor feel, nor move, nor speak, nor grasp, nor perceive, nor know. He began with his death before his life, and with his weakness before his strength, and with his ignorance [jahl] before his knowledge [‘ilm], and with his blindness before his sight, and with his deafness before his hearing, and with his muteness before his speech, and with his misguidance [dalalah] before his guidance [huda], and with his poverty before his wealth, and with his incapacity before his power. This is the meaning of His saying, "From what thing did We create man? From a mixed drop [nutfah amshaj]," and the meaning of His saying, "Has there come upon man a period of time when he was not a thing mentioned? Indeed, We created man from a mixed drop [nutfah amshaj] to test him." Likewise, He created him first, then bestowed favor upon him, saying, "Then the way [al-sabil] We made easy for him." And this is a reference to what was made easy for him during the period of his life until death. And likewise He said, "From a mixed drop [nutfah amshaj] We test him, so We made him hearing and seeing. Indeed, We guided him to the way [al-sabil]—whether he be grateful or ungrateful." Its meaning is that He gave him life after he was a lifeless, dead mineral, dust [turab] first and a drop [nutfah] second; and He gave him hearing after he was deaf, and sight after he was devoid of vision, and strength after weakness, and knowledge [‘ilm] after ignorance [jahl]; and He created for him limbs with their wonders and signs after their absence; and enriched him after poverty, and satisfied him after hunger, and clothed him after nakedness, and guided him [hadahu] after misguidance [dalalah]. So look how He managed him and formed him, and to the way [al-sabil] how He made it easy, and to the transgression of man how ungrateful he is, and to the ignorance [jahl] of man how He manifests it? So He said, "Does man not consider that We created him from a drop [nutfah]? Then at once he is a clear adversary. And of His signs is that He created you from dust [turab]; then, at once, you are human beings dispersing." So look at the favor of Allah upon him, how He transferred him from that lowliness, insignificance, baseness, and filth to this elevation and honor—so he became existent after non-existence [‘adam], alive after death, speaking after muteness, seeing after blindness, strong after weakness, knowing [‘aliman] after ignorance [jahl], guided [mahdiyyan] after misguidance [dalalah], capable after incapacity, and rich after poverty? For in his essence he was nothing [la shay'a]—and what thing is more base than nothing? And what insignificance is less than pure non-existence [al-‘adam al-mahd]? Then, by Allah, he became something [shay'an]. He only created him from the lowly dust [al-turab al-dhalil] that is trodden underfoot and the filthy drop [al-nutfah al-qadirah] after pure non-existence [al-‘adam al-mahd] also, so that He might make him know the baseness of his essence, that he may thereby know himself. And He only perfected the favor upon him so that he may know by it his Lord and know by it His greatness and majesty, and that grandeur [al-kibriya'] is not fitting except for Him, Glorified and Exalted. And for that reason, He bestowed favor upon him, saying, "Have We not made for him two eyes, a tongue, and two lips, and guided him [hadaynahu] to the two ways [al-najdayn]?" And He made known his baseness first, saying, "Was he not a drop of sperm emitted? Then he was a clinging clot [‘alaqah]." Then He mentioned His favor upon him, saying, "Then He created and proportioned, and made from him the two sexes, male and female," so that his existence may continue through procreation, just as his existence first occurred through invention. So, he whose beginning is this and whose states are these—from where does he get arrogance, grandeur [al-kibriya'], pride, and boastfulness, when he is, in truth, the basest of the base and the weakest of the weak?

a.g: Indeed, We guided him to the way, be he grateful or be he ungrateful.
Indeed, We have prepared for the disbelievers chains and shackles and a blaze.
Indeed, the righteous will drink from a cup [of wine] whose mixture is of Kafur,
A spring of which the [righteous] servants of Allah will drink; they will make it gush forth in force [and abundance].
They [are those who] fulfill [their] vows and fear a Day whose evil will be widespread.
And they give food in spite of love for it to the needy, the orphan, and the captive,
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 5
Indeed, it is related: 'Utbah the youth craved meat for seven years. Then, after that time, he said: "I became ashamed of my soul [nafs] that I had been repelling it for seven years—year after year." So he bought a piece of meat with bread, roasted it, and placed it upon a loaf. Then he met an orphan boy and said, "Are you not the son of so-and-so, whose father has died?" He said, "Yes." So he gave it to him. They said: And he began to weep and recite, "And they give food, despite their love for it, to the needy, the orphan, and the captive..." Then he did not taste it after that. And he remained craving dates for years. Then, one day, he bought dates for a *qirat* and kept them until night to break his fast upon them. He said: "Then a strong wind blew until the world [dunya] grew dark, and the people were alarmed." 'Utbah turned to his soul [nafs] and said: "This is for my audacity against you and my purchasing dates for a *qirat*." Then he said to his soul [nafs]: "I do not think the people are being taken except because of your sin? On the condition that you shall not taste it."

a.g: [Saying], "We feed you only for the countenance of Allah. We wish not from you reward or gratitude.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol3 book 8a
Know that ostentation [riya'] is forbidden, and the ostentatious one [al-mura'i] is detested in the sight of God [Allah], and the verses [ayat], the reports [akhbar], and the traditions [athar] have borne witness to this. As for the verses: His saying, the Most High, "We feed you only for the countenance of God [li-wajhi Allah]; we desire no reward from you, nor thanks" — thus He praised the sincere ones [al-mukhlisin] by negating every desire [irada] other than the countenance of God [wajh Allah], and ostentation [riya'] is its opposite.

a.g: Indeed, We fear from our Lord a Day austere and distressful."
So Allah will protect them from the evil of that Day and give them radiance and happiness
And will reward them for what they patiently endured [with] a garden [in Paradise] and silk [garments].
[They will be] reclining therein on adorned couches. They will not see therein any [burning] sun or [freezing] cold.
And near above them are its shades, and its [fruit] to be picked will be lowered in compliance.
And there will be circulated among them vessels of silver and cups having been [created] clear [as glass],
Clear glasses [made] from silver of which they have determined the measure.
And they will be given to drink a cup [of wine] whose mixture is of ginger
[From] a fountain within Paradise named Salsabeel.
There will circulate among them young boys made eternal. When you see them, you would think them [as beautiful as] scattered pearls.
And when you look there [in Paradise], you will see pleasure and great dominion.
Upon the inhabitants will be green garments of fine silk and brocade. And they will be adorned with bracelets of silver, and their Lord will give them a purifying drink.
[And it will be said], "Indeed, this is for you a reward, and your effort has been appreciated."
Indeed, it is We who have sent down to you, [O Muhammad], the Qur'an progressively.
So be patient for the decision of your Lord and do not obey from among them a sinner or ungrateful [disbeliever].
And mention the name of your Lord [in prayer] morning and evening
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 10
Indeed, love [mahabba] and intimate communion [uns] with God, the Exalted, are not attained except through the perpetual remembrance [dhikr] of the Beloved and constant adherence to it. And knowledge [ma'rifa] of Him is not realized except through the total absorption of thought [fikr] in His Essence, His Attributes, and His Actions, for there is nothing in existence besides Him and His actions. And the continuity of remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] will not be facilitated except by abandoning the world [dunya] and its desires, and restricting oneself from it to the measure of necessity. And that is not accomplished except by occupying all the times of night and day with the duties of remembrances [adhkar] and contemplations [afkar]. The soul [nafs], due to what it is created upon of weariness and boredom, does not have patience for a single pattern of the means of remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr]. Rather, if it is returned to it, it shows aversion. And God, the Exalted, does not tire until you tire. So from the necessity of gentleness with it is to refresh it by moving from one mode to another and from one type to another according to each time, so that its pleasure [ladhdha] increases through the transition, its desire [raghba] is magnified by the pleasure, and its adherence [muwazaba] endures through the endurance of the desire. For that reason, the litanies [awrad] are divided into different divisions. And it is necessary that remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] occupy all times or most of them. For the soul [nafs], by its nature, is inclined to the pleasures [ladhadh] of the world [dunya]. So if the servant spends half of his times on the arrangements and permissible desires of the world [dunya] and the other half on acts of worship, the side of inclination to the world [dunya] outweighs due to its conformity with nature [tab'], since the time is equal. So how can they be balanced when nature [tab'] gives weight to one of them? For the outward and inward assist each other in the matters of the world [dunya], and the heart [qalb] becomes pure and single-minded in seeking it. As for being turned back to acts of worship, it is forced, and the sincerity [ikhlas] and presence [hudur] of the heart [qalb] in it are not safe except at some times. So whoever wishes to enter Paradise without reckoning, let him occupy all his times in obedience [ta'a]. And whoever wishes for the scale of his good deeds to outweigh and the balances of his goodness to be heavy, let him occupy most of his times in obedience [ta'a]. If he mixes a righteous deed with another that is evil, then his affair is perilous. But hope is not cut off, and pardon from the generosity of God is awaited. Perhaps God, the Exalted, will forgive him by His bounty and generosity. This is what has been unveiled to the observers by the light of insight [basira]. If you are not of its people, then look at the address of God, the Exalted, to His Messenger and take it by the light of faith [iman]. For God, the Exalted, has said: **"And remember the name of your Lord morning and evening, and during the night prostrate to Him and glorify Him a long night."** This indicates that the path to God, the Exalted, is the vigilance over times and populating them with litanies [awrad] in a manner of continuity, to achieve the continuity of remembrance [dhikr] and contemplation [fikr] in all periods of night and day. Thus the heart [qalb] becomes occupied with intimate communion [uns] and love [mahabba], detached from the pleasures of the world [dunya], and absorbed in seeking the Countenance of the Most Generous.
Vol1 book 10
Indeed, love [mahabba] and intimacy [uns] are not attained except through the constant remembrance [dhikr] of the Beloved and persistence in it, and knowledge [ma'rifa] of God, glorified is He, is not attained except through constant reflection [fikr] upon Him and His attributes and His actions, for in existence there is nothing but God, the Exalted, and His actions. And constant remembrance and reflection will not be made easy except by bidding farewell to the world [dunya] and its desires and being content with it only to the extent of sufficiency and necessity, and all of that is not perfected except by immersing the times of night and day in the duties of remembrances and reflections. And the soul [nafs], due to what it is created upon of weariness and boredom, does not have patience for a single mode of the means that assist in remembrance and reflection; rather, if it is returned to one pattern, it displays boredom and a sense of burden, and indeed God, the Exalted, does not weary until you weary. So from the necessity of gentleness with it is that it be refreshed by shifting from one mode to another and from one type to another according to each time, so that its pleasure is increased by the transition, and its desire is magnified by the pleasure, and its persistence endures through the endurance of desire. Therefore, the litanies [awrad] are divided into different divisions, and remembrance and reflection should encompass all times or most of them. For the soul, by its nature, is inclined to the pleasures of the world; if the servant spends half his times on the arrangements of the world and its permissible desires, for example, and the other half on acts of worship, the side of inclination to the world is given weight because it agrees with his nature, since the time is equal—so how can they be balanced when nature gives weight to one of them, for the outward and inward cooperate in worldly matters and the heart [qalb] becomes pure and single-minded in seeking them? As for being turned back to acts of worship, it is forced, and the sincerity [ikhlas] of the heart and its presence therein is not safe except at some times. So whoever wishes to enter Paradise without reckoning, let him immerse his times in obedience. And whoever wishes for the scale of his good deeds to be given weight and the balances of his goodness to be heavy, let him occupy most of his times in obedience. If he mixes a righteous deed with another evil one, then his affair is perilous, but hope is not cut off, and pardon from the generosity of God is awaited; perhaps God, the Exalted, will forgive him by His bounty and generosity. This is what has been unveiled to the observers by the light of insight [basira]; if you are not of its people, then look to the address of God, the Exalted, to His Messenger and take it by the light of faith [iman], for God, the Exalted, has said: **"And remember the name of your Lord morning and evening"**, making clear that the path to God, the Exalted, is the observance of times and populating them with litanies on the path of constancy, to realize the constant remembrance and reflection which is the foundation of love and knowledge.

a.g: And during the night prostrate to Him and exalt Him a long [part of the] night.
Indeed, these [disbelievers] love the immediate and leave behind them a grave Day.
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book2
Indeed, when the cunning [makr] of Satan spread among all creation, Allah sent the angels to the messengers and revealed to them what the enemy had accomplished in destroying and misleading the creation. So they busied themselves with calling the creation to the True, Eternal Kingdom [al-Mulk al-Haqiqi] over the metaphorical kingdom [al-mulk al-majazi] which has no reality if it is safe, and no permanence at all. So they called out among them: **"O you who have believed, what is [the matter] with you that when you are told to go forth in the cause of Allah, you adhere heavily to the earth? Are you satisfied with the life of this world [al-hayat al-dunya] from the Hereafter? But what is the enjoyment of the life of this world compared to the Hereafter except a little."** (Quran 9:38) So the Torah, the Gospel, the Psalms, the Criterion [al-Furqan], the Scrolls of Moses and Abraham, and every revealed Book—none was sent down except to call the creation to the Everlasting, Eternal Kingdom. And what is intended for them is that they be kings in this world and kings in the Hereafter. As for kingship in this world, it is through asceticism [zuhd] in it and contentment with the little of it. And as for kingship in the Hereafter, it is through nearness to Allah, the Most High, attained by a permanence [baqa'] in which there is no annihilation, and a might ['izz] in which there is no humiliation, and a coolness of the eye [qurrat 'ayn] concealed in this world, which no soul [nafs] among the souls knows. And Satan calls them to kingship in this world, knowing that the kingship of the Hereafter is lost by it, for this world and the Hereafter are co-wives. And knowing that this world will not be safe for him either, for even if it were safe for him, he would envy it also. But kingship in this world is not free from disputes, disturbances, the length of worries in management, and likewise all the causes of status. Then, however much it is secured and the causes are perfected, the lifespan ends. **"Until when the earth has taken on its adornment and is beautified and its people think that they have control over it, Our command comes to it by night or by day, and We make it as a harvest, as if it had not flourished yesterday."** (Quran 10:24) So Allah, the Most High, struck a parable for it, saying, the Most High: **"And present to them the example of the life of this world as [being] like water which We send down from the sky, and the vegetation of the earth mingles with it and [then] it becomes dry remnants, scattered by the winds."** (Quran 18:45) And asceticism [zuhd] in this world, because it is a present kingship, Satan envied it and turned them away from it. And the meaning of asceticism is that the servant masters his passion [shahwa] and his anger [ghadab], so they become subservient to the motive of religion and the indication of faith. And this is a kingship by deserving [istihqaq], for by it its possessor becomes free, and by the domination of passion over him, he becomes...

a.g: We have created them and strengthened their forms, and when We will, We can change their likenesses with [complete] alteration.
Indeed, this is a reminder, so he who wills may take to his Lord a way.
And you do not will except that Allah wills. Indeed, Allah is ever Knowing and Wise.
He admits whom He wills into His mercy; but the wrongdoers - He has prepared for them a painful punishment.
